[Fannie]35-fannie was summoned , and when the matter was explained to [her]35-fannie , first gave evidences of giving way to grief , but when [the detective]311-the detective began to question [her]35-fannie , [she]35-fannie calmed [herself]35-fannie and answered directly just as [[her]35-fannie husband]181-her husband had .

" Well posted , "[55-mr. oakley] sneered [Oakley]55-mr. oakley . " Arrest [that man]1674-that man . "[55-mr. oakley]

[Berry]34-berry had begun to look more hopeful during [Fannie]35-fannie 's recital , but now the ashen look came back into [his]34-berry face . At the word " arrest "[133-his wife] [[his]34-berry wife]133-his wife collapsed utterly , and sobbed on [[her]133-his wife husband]181-her husband 's shoulder .

" Send [the woman]268-the woman away . "[133-his wife]

" [I]35-fannie wo n't go , "[35-fannie] cried [Fannie]35-fannie stoutly ; " [I]35-fannie 'll stay right hyeah by [[my]35-fannie husband]1676-my husband . [You]34-berry sha'n't drive [me]35-fannie away f'om [him]1674-that man . "[35-fannie]

[Berry]34-berry turned to [[his]34-berry employer]138-his employer . " [You]138-his employer b'lieve dat [I]34-berry stole [f'om dis house]1677-f'om dis house aftah all [de]138-his employer yeahs [I]34-berry ' ve been in it , aftah de caih [I]34-berry took of [yo]138-his employer ' money an ' [yo]138-his employer ' valybles , aftah de way [I]34-berry ' ve put [you]138-his employer to bed f'om [many a dinnah]1678-many a dinnah , an ' [you]138-his employer woke up to fin ' all [yo]138-his employer ' money safe ? Now , can [you]138-his employer b'lieve dis ? "[34-berry]

[His]34-berry voice broke , and [he]34-berry ended with a cry .

" Yes , [I]34-berry believe it , [[you]138-his employer thief]1669-you thief , yes . Take [him]392-his man away . "[34-berry]

[Berry]34-berry 's eyes were bloodshot as [he]34-berry replied , " [Den]56-den , damn [you]138-his employer ! damn [you]138-his employer ! ef dat 's all dese yeahs counted fu ' , [I]34-berry wish [I]34-berry had a - stoled it . "[34-berry]

[Oakley]55-mr. oakley made a step forward , and [[his]55-mr. oakley man]392-his man did likewise , but [the officer]331-the officer stepped between [them]394-them .

" Take that damned hound away , or , by [God]57-god ! [I]34-berry 'll do [him]392-his man violence ! "[34-berry]

[The two men]204-the two men stood fiercely facing [each other]192-each other , then the handcuffs were snapped on [the servant]386-the servant 's wrist .

" No , no , "[35-fannie] shrieked [Fannie]35-fannie , " [you]138-his employer must n't , [you]138-his employer must n't . Oh , [[my]35-fannie Gawd]1680-my gawd ! [he]392-his man ain ' t [no thief]1681-no thief . [I]35-fannie 'll go to [Mis ' Oakley]58-mis ' oakley . [She]402-her mistress nevah will believe it . "[35-fannie] [She]35-fannie sped from [the room]292-the room .

The commotion had called a crowd of [curious servants]399-curious servants into [the hall]287-the hall . [Fannie]35-fannie hardly saw [them]401-them as [she]35-fannie dashed among [them]401-them , crying for [[her]35-fannie mistress]402-her mistress . In a moment [she]35-fannie returned , dragging [Mrs. Oakley]40-mrs. oakley by the hand .

" Tell 'em , oh , tell ['em]1682-'em , [Miss Leslie]49-leslie , dat [you]49-leslie do n't believe it . Do n't let ['em]1682-'em ' rest [Berry]34-berry . "[35-fannie]

" Why , [Fannie]35-fannie , [I]181-her husband ca n't do anything . It all seems perfectly plain , and [Mr. Oakley]55-mr. oakley knows better than any of [us]1683-us , [you]35-fannie know . "[181-her husband]

[Fannie]35-fannie , [her]35-fannie last hope gone , flung [herself]35-fannie on the floor , crying , " O Gawd ! [O Gawd]59-gawd ! [he]34-berry 's gone fu ' sho ' ! "[35-fannie]

[[Her]35-fannie husband]181-her husband bent over [her]35-fannie , the tears dropping from [his]181-her husband eyes . " [Nevah]60-nevah min ' , [Fannie]35-fannie , "[181-her husband] [he]181-her husband said , " nevah min ' . Hit 's boun ' to come out all right . "[181-her husband]

[She]35-fannie raised [her]35-fannie head , and seizing [his]181-her husband manacled hands pressed them to [her]35-fannie breast , wailing in a low monotone , " Gone ! gone ! "[181-her husband]

[They]404-they disengaged [her]35-fannie hands , and led [Berry]34-berry away .

" Take [her]35-fannie out , "[40-mrs. oakley] said [Oakley]40-mrs. oakley sternly to [the servants]405-the servants ; and [they]404-they lifted [her]35-fannie up and carried [her]35-fannie away in a sort of dumb stupor that was half a swoon .

[They]404-they took [her]35-fannie to [[her]35-fannie little cottage]406-her little cottage , and laid [her]35-fannie down until [she]35-fannie could come to [herself]35-fannie and the full horror of [her]35-fannie situation burst upon [her]35-fannie .

V

THE JUSTICE OF [MEN]242-men

The arrest of [Berry Hamilton]34-berry on the charge preferred by [[his]34-berry employer]138-his employer was the cause of unusual commotion in [the town]172-the town . Both [the accuser]410-the accuser and [the accused]411-the accused were well known to [the citizens]412-the citizens , white and [black,--Maurice Oakley]40-mrs. oakley as [a solid man of business]413-a solid man of business , and [Berry]34-berry as [an honest , sensible negro]414-an honest , sensible negro , and [the pink of good servants]415-the pink of good servants . The evening papers had a full story of the crime , which closed by saying that [the prisoner]416-the prisoner had amassed a considerable sum of money , it was very likely from a long series of smaller peculations .

It seems a strange irony upon the force of right living , that [this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing , should find [so few who even at the first telling]418-so few who even at the first telling doubted the story of [his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing guilt . [Many people]419-many people began to remember things that had looked particularly suspicious in [his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing dealings . [Some others]420-some others said , " [I]420-some others did n't think it of [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing . "[420-some others] There were only a few who dared to say , " [I]420-some others do n't believe it of [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing . "[420-some others]

The first act of [[his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing lodge]163-his lodge , " [The Tribe of Benjamin]188-the tribe of benjamin , "[417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing] whose treasurer [he]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing was , was to have [his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing accounts audited , when [they]422-they should have been visiting [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing with comfort , and [they]422-they seemed personally grieved when [his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing books were found to be straight . [The A. M. E. church , of which [he]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing had been [an honest and active member]424-an honest and active member , hastened to disavow sympathy with [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing , and to purge [itself]423-the a. m. e. church , of which he had been an honest and active member , hastened to disavow sympathy with him , and to purge itself of contamination by turning him out of contamination by turning [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing out]423-the a. m. e. church , of which he had been an honest and active member , hastened to disavow sympathy with him , and to purge itself of contamination by turning him out . [[His]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing friends]425-his friends were afraid to visit [him]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing and were silent when [[his]417-this man , who had never been arrested before , who had never even been suspected of wrong - doing enemies]426-his enemies gloated . On every side one might have asked , Where is charity ? and gone away empty .

In [the black people of [the town]172-the town]427-the black people of the town the strong influence of slavery was still operative , and with one accord [they]427-the black people of the town turned away from [one of [[their]427-the black people of the town own kind]430-their own kind upon [whom had been set the ban of the white people]431-whom had been set the ban of the white people 's displeasure]429-one of their own kind upon whom had been set the ban of the white people 's displeasure . If [they]427-the black people of the town had sympathy , [they]427-the black people of the town dared not show it . [Their]427-the black people of the town own interests , the safety of [their]427-the black people of the town own positions and firesides , demanded that [they]427-the black people of the town stand aloof from [the criminal]432-the criminal . Not then , not now , nor has it ever been true , although it has been claimed , that [negroes]433-negroes either harbour or sympathise with [the criminal of [their]433-negroes kind]434-the criminal of their kind . [They]427-the black people of the town did not dare to do it before the sixties . [They]427-the black people of the town do not dare to do it now . [They]427-the black people of the town have brought down as a heritage from the days of [their]427-the black people of the town bondage both fear and disloyalty . So [Berry]34-berry was unbefriended while the storm raged around [him]34-berry . [The cell where [they]427-the black people of the town had placed [him]34-berry]435-the cell where they had placed him was kind to [him]34-berry , and [he]34-berry could not hear the envious and sneering comments that went on about [him]34-berry . This was kind , for the tongues of [[his]34-berry enemies]426-his enemies were not .

" Tell [me]1622-one , tell [me]1622-one , "[1622-one] said [one]1622-one , " [you]34-berry need n't tell [me]1622-one dat a bird kin fly so high dat [he]34-berry don ' have to come down some time . An ' w'en [he]34-berry do light , [honey]1685-honey , [[my]1622-one Lawd]1686-my lawd , how [he]34-berry flop ! "[1622-one]

" [Mistah Rich Niggah]61-mistah rich niggah , "[438-another] said [another]438-another . " [He]34-berry wanted to dress [[his]34-berry wife]133-his wife an ' chillen lak [white folks]1688-white folks , did [he]34-berry ? Well , [he]34-berry foun ' out , [he]34-berry foun ' out . By de time [de]1689-de jedge git thoo wid [him]34-berry [he]34-berry wo n't be hol'in ' [his]34-berry haid so high . "[438-another]

" Wy , [dat gal o ' his'n]1690-dat gal o ' his'n , "[62-old isaac brown] broke in [old Isaac Brown]62-old isaac brown indignantly , " w'y , [she]1690-dat gal o ' his'n would n ' speak to [[my]62-old isaac brown gal]1691-my gal , [Minty]63-minty , when [she]1690-dat gal o ' his'n met huh on [de street]1692-de street . [I]62-old isaac brown reckon [she]1690-dat gal o ' his'n come down off'n huh high hoss now . "[62-old isaac brown]

The fact of the matter was that [Minty Brown]63-minty was no better than [she]63-minty should have been , and did not deserve to be spoken to . But none of this was taken into account either by [the speaker]439-the speaker or [the hearers]440-the hearers . [The man]269-the man was down , it was time to strike .

[The women]277-the women too joined [their]277-the women shrill voices to the general cry , and were loud in [their]277-the women abuse of [the Hamiltons]443-the hamiltons and in disparagement of [their]277-the women high - toned airs .

" [I]444-one old crone knowed it , [I]444-one old crone knowed it , "[444-one old crone] mumbled [one old crone]444-one old crone , rolling [her]444-one old crone bleared and jealous eyes with glee . " W'enevah [you]1693-you see [niggahs]1694-niggahs gittin ' so high dat [dey own folks]1695-dey own folks ain ' good enough fu ' 'em , look out . "[444-one old crone]

" W'y , [la]1696-la , [Aunt Chloe]64-aunt chloe [I]444-one old crone knowed it too . [Dem people]1697-dem people got so owdacious proud dat [dey]1695-dey own folks would n't walk up to de collection table no mo ' at chu'ch , but allus set an ' waited twell [de basket]1698-de basket was passed erroun ' . "[444-one old crone]

" Hit 's de livin ' trufe , an ' [I]444-one old crone 's been seein ' it all ' long . [I]444-one old crone ai n't said nuffin ' , but [I]444-one old crone knowed what ' uz gwine to happen . [Ol' Chloe]64-aunt chloe ai n't lived all dese yeahs fu ' nuffin ' , an ' ef [she]64-aunt chloe got [de]1695-dey own folks gif ' o ' secon ' sight , ' t ai n't fu ' huh to say . "[444-one old crone]

[The women]277-the women suddenly became interested in this half assertion , and [the old hag]446-the old hag , seeing that [she]446-the old hag had made the desired impression , lapsed into silence .

[The whites]447-the whites were not neglecting to review and comment on the case also . It had been long since so great a bit of wrong - doing in [a negro]1605-a negro had given [them]447-the whites cause for speculation and recrimination .

" [I]65-old horace talbot tell [you]1699-you , "[65-old horace talbot] said [old Horace Talbot]65-old horace talbot , who was noted for [his]65-old horace talbot kindliness towards [people of colour]449-people of colour , " [I]450-i tell [you]1699-you , [I]450-i pity that darky more than [I]450-i blame [him]453-the old gentleman . Now , here 's [my]450-i theory . "[450-i] [They]450-i were in [the bar of [the Continental Hotel]452-the continental hotel]451-the bar of the continental hotel , and [the old gentleman]453-the old gentleman sipped [his]453-the old gentleman liquor as [he]453-the old gentleman talked . " It 's just like this : [The North]66-the north thought [they]66-the north were doing a great thing when [they]66-the north come down here and freed [all the slaves]1700-all the slaves . [They]66-the north thought [they]66-the north were doing a great thing , and [I]453-the old gentleman ' m not saying a word against [them]66-the north . [I]453-the old gentleman give [them]66-the north the credit for having the courage of [their]66-the north convictions . But [I]453-the old gentleman maintain that [they]66-the north were all wrong , now , in turning [these people]1701-these people loose upon [the country]213-the country the way [they]66-the north did , without knowledge of what the first principle of liberty was . The natural result is that [these people]1701-these people are irresponsible . [They]1701-these people are unacquainted with the ways of [our]1704-our higher civilisation , and it 'll take [them]1701-these people a long time to learn . [You]1705-you know [Rome]9-rome was n't built in a day . [I]453-the old gentleman know [Berry]34-berry , and [I]453-the old gentleman ' ve known [him]34-berry for a long while , and a politer , likelier darky than [him]34-berry [you]1705-you would have to go far to find . And [I]453-the old gentleman have n't the least doubt in [the world]1706-the world that [he]34-berry took that money absolutely without a thought of wrong , [sir]1646-sir , absolutely . [He]34-berry saw it . [He]34-berry took it , and to [his]34-berry mental process , that was the end of it . To [him]34-berry there was no injury inflicted on [any one]1604-any one , there was no crime committed . [His]34-berry elemental reasoning was simply this : [This man]1709-this man has more money than [I]453-the old gentleman have ; here is some of [his]1709-this man surplus,--I 'll just take it . Why , [gentlemen]1710-gentlemen , [I]453-the old gentleman maintain that [that man]1674-that man took that money with the same innocence of purpose with which one of [[our]1712-our servants]1713-our servants a few years ago would have appropriated a stray ham . "[453-the old gentleman]

" [I]68-beachfield disagree with [you]1646-sir entirely , [Mr. Talbot]67-mr. talbot , "[68-beachfield] broke in [Mr. Beachfield Davis]68-beachfield , who was a mighty hunter.--"Make mine the same , [Jerry]69-jerry , only add a little syrup.--I disagree with [you]69-jerry . It 's simply total depravity , that 's all . [All niggers]1714-all niggers are alike , and there 's no use trying to do anything with [them]1714-all niggers . Look at [that man]1674-that man , [Dodson]70-dodson , of [mine]453-the old gentleman . [I]68-beachfield had [one of the finest young hounds in [the State]1717-the state]1716-one of the finest young hounds in the state . [You]69-jerry know that white pup of [mine]453-the old gentleman , [Mr. Talbot]67-mr. talbot , that [I]68-beachfield bought from [Hiram Gaskins]71-hiram gaskins ? [Mighty fine breed]1718-mighty fine breed . Well , [I]68-beachfield was spendin ' all [my]68-beachfield time and patience trainin ' that dog in the daytime . At night [I]68-beachfield put [him]1716-one of the finest young hounds in the state in [that nigger]1719-that nigger 's care to feed and bed . Well , do [you]69-jerry know , [I]68-beachfield came [home]210-home the other night and found [that black rascal]1721-that black rascal gone ? [I]68-beachfield went out to see if the dog was properly bedded , and by [Jove]72-jove , the dog was gone too . Then [I]68-beachfield got suspicious . When [a nigger]1722-a nigger and a dog go out together at night , [one]1622-one draws certain conclusions . [I]68-beachfield thought [I]68-beachfield had heard bayin ' way out towards [the edge of [the town]172-the town]1724-the edge of the town . So [I]68-beachfield stayed outside and watched . In about an hour here came [Dodson]70-dodson with a possum hung over [his]70-dodson shoulder and [my]68-beachfield dog trottin ' at [his]70-dodson heels . [He]1716-one of the finest young hounds in the state 'd been possum huntin ' with [my]68-beachfield hound -- with the finest hound in [the State]1717-the state , [sir]1646-sir . Now , [I]68-beachfield appeal to [you]1728-you all , [gentlemen]1710-gentlemen , if that ai n't total depravity , what is total depravity ? "[68-beachfield]

" Not total depravity , [Beachfield]68-beachfield , [I]73-old horace maintain , but the very irresponsibility of which [I]73-old horace have spoken . Why , [gentlemen]1710-gentlemen , [I]73-old horace foresee the day when [these people themselves]1731-these people themselves shall come to [us]1732-us Southerners of [their]1731-these people themselves own accord and ask to be re - enslaved until such time as [they]1731-these people themselves shall be fit for freedom . "[73-old horace] [Old Horace]73-old horace was nothing if not logical .

" Well , do [you]74-colonel saunders think there 's any doubt of the darky 's guilt ? "[74-colonel saunders] asked [Colonel Saunders]74-colonel saunders hesitatingly . [He]74-colonel saunders was [the only man who had ever thought of such a possibility]454-the only man who had ever thought of such a possibility . [They]455-they turned on [him]74-colonel saunders as if [he]74-colonel saunders had been some strange , unnatural animal .

" Any doubt ! "[73-old horace] cried [Old Horace]73-old horace .

" Any doubt ! "[68-beachfield] exclaimed [Mr. Davis]68-beachfield .

" Any doubt ? "[456-the rest] almost shrieked [the rest]456-the rest . " Why , there can be no doubt . Why , [Colonel]74-colonel saunders , what are [you]74-colonel saunders thinking of ? Tell [us]1732-us who has got the money if [he]74-colonel saunders has n't ? Tell [us]1732-us where on earth [the nigger]1733-the nigger got the money [he]74-colonel saunders 's been putting in [the bank]1649-the bank ? Doubt ? Why , there is n't the least doubt about it . "[456-the rest]

" Certainly , certainly , "[457-the colonel] said [the Colonel]457-the colonel , " but [I]457-the colonel thought , of course , [he]74-colonel saunders might have saved it . There are several of [those people]1735-those people , [you]74-colonel saunders know , who do a little business and have bank accounts . "[457-the colonel]

" Yes , but [they]1735-those people are in some sort of business . [This man]1709-this man makes only thirty dollars a month . Do n't [you]74-colonel saunders see ? "[457-the colonel]

[The Colonel]457-the colonel saw , or said [he]457-the colonel did . And [he]457-the colonel did not answer what [he]457-the colonel might have answered , that [Berry]34-berry had no rent and no board to pay . [His]34-berry clothes came from [[his]34-berry master]459-his master , and [Kitty]38-kitty and [Fannie]35-fannie looked to [[their]460-their mistress]461-their mistress for the larger number of [their]460-their supplies . [He]457-the colonel did not call to [their]460-their minds that [Fannie]35-fannie [herself]35-fannie made fifteen dollars a month , and that for two years [Joe]37-joe had been supporting [himself]37-joe . These things did not come up , and as far as the opinion of [the gentlemen assembled in the Continental bar]462-the gentlemen assembled in the continental bar went , [Berry]34-berry was already proven guilty .

As for [the prisoner]416-the prisoner [himself]416-the prisoner , after the first day when [he]416-the prisoner had pleaded " Not guilty "[416-the prisoner] and been bound over to [the Grand Jury]464-the grand jury , [he]416-the prisoner had fallen into a sort of dazed calm that was like the stupor produced by a drug . [He]416-the prisoner took little heed of what went on around [him]416-the prisoner . The shock had been too sudden for [him]416-the prisoner , and it was as if [his]416-the prisoner reason had been for the time unseated . That it was not permanently overthrown was evidenced by [his]416-the prisoner waking to the most acute pain and grief whenever [Fannie]35-fannie came to [him]416-the prisoner . Then [he]416-the prisoner would toss and moan and give vent to [his]416-the prisoner sorrow in passionate complaints .

" [I]416-the prisoner did n't tech [his]416-the prisoner money , [Fannie]35-fannie , [you]35-fannie know [I]416-the prisoner did n't . [I]416-the prisoner wo'ked fu ' every cent of dat money , an ' [I]416-the prisoner saved it [myself]416-the prisoner . Oh , [I]416-the prisoner 'll nevah be able to git a job ag'in . [Me]416-the prisoner in de lock - up -- [me]416-the prisoner , aftah all dese yeahs ! "[416-the prisoner]

Beyond this , apparently , [his]416-the prisoner mind could not go . That [his]416-the prisoner detention was anything more than temporary never seemed to enter [his]416-the prisoner mind . That [he]416-the prisoner would be convicted and sentenced was as far from possibility as the skies from [the earth]465-the earth . If [he]416-the prisoner saw visions of a long sojourn in [prison]466-prison , it was only as a nightmare half consciously experienced and which with the struggle must give way before the waking .

[Fannie]35-fannie was utterly hopeless . [She]35-fannie had laid down whatever pride had been [hers]35-fannie and gone to plead with [Maurice Oakley]39-maurice for [[her]35-fannie husband]181-her husband 's freedom , and [she]35-fannie had seen [his]181-her husband hard , set face . [She]35-fannie had gone upon [her]35-fannie knees before [[his]181-her husband wife]133-his wife to cite [Berry]34-berry 's long fidelity .

" Oh , [Mis ' Oakley]58-mis ' oakley , "[35-fannie] [she]35-fannie cried , " ef [he]181-her husband did steal de money , [we]1737-we ' ve got enough saved to [mek]1738-mek it good . Let [him]181-her husband go ! let [him]181-her husband go ! "[35-fannie]

" Then [you]58-mis ' oakley admit that [he]181-her husband did steal ? "[40-mrs. oakley] [Mrs. Oakley]40-mrs. oakley had taken [her]35-fannie up sharply .

" Oh , [I]35-fannie did n't say dat ; [I]35-fannie did n't mean dat . "[35-fannie]

" That will do , [Fannie]35-fannie . [I]35-fannie understand perfectly . [You]58-mis ' oakley should have confessed that long ago . "[35-fannie]

" But [I]35-fannie ai n't confessin ' ! [I]35-fannie ai n't ! [He]181-her husband did n't---- "[35-fannie]

" [You]58-mis ' oakley may go . "[35-fannie]

[The stricken woman]469-the stricken woman reeled out of [[her]469-the stricken woman mistress]402-her mistress 's presence , and [Mrs. Oakley]40-mrs. oakley told [[her]40-mrs. oakley husband]181-her husband that night , with tears in [her]40-mrs. oakley eyes , how disappointed [she]40-mrs. oakley was with [Fannie,--that]472-fannie,--that [the woman]268-the woman had known it all along , and had only just confessed . It was just one more link in the chain that was surely and not too slowly forging itself about [Berry Hamilton]34-berry .

Of [all the family]474-all the family [Joe]37-joe was [the only one who burned with a fierce indignation]475-the only one who burned with a fierce indignation . [He]37-joe knew that [[his]37-joe father]180-his father was innocent , and [his]37-joe very helplessness made a fever in [his]37-joe soul . [Dandy]477-dandy as [he]37-joe was , [he]37-joe was loyal , and when [he]37-joe saw [[his]37-joe mother]478-his mother 's tears and [[his]37-joe sister]479-his sister 's shame , something rose within [him]37-joe that had it been given play might have made [a man]1563-a man of [him]37-joe , but , being crushed , died and rotted , and in the compost it made all the evil of [his]37-joe nature flourished . The looks and gibes of [[his]37-joe fellow - employees at [the barber - shop]482-the barber - shop]481-his fellow - employees at the barber - shop forced [him]37-joe to leave [his]37-joe work [there]1594-there . [Kit]38-kitty , bowed with shame and grief , dared not appear upon [the streets]484-the streets , where [the girls who had envied [her]38-kitty]485-the girls who had envied her now hooted at [her]38-kitty . So [the little family]486-the little family was shut in upon itself away from fellowship and sympathy .

[Joe]37-joe went seldom to see [[his]37-joe father]180-his father . [He]37-joe was not heartless ; but the citadel of [his]37-joe long desired and much vaunted manhood trembled before the sight of [[his]37-joe father]180-his father 's abject misery . The lines came round [his]37-joe lips , and lines too must have come round [his]37-joe heart . [Poor fellow]1623-poor fellow , [he]37-joe was too young for this forcing process , and in the hot - house of pain [he]37-joe only grew [an acrid , unripe cynic]490-an acrid , unripe cynic .

At the sitting of the Grand Jury [Berry]34-berry was indicted . [His]34-berry trial followed soon , and [the town]172-the town turned out to see it . [Some]492-some came to laugh and scoff , but these , [[his]34-berry enemies]426-his enemies , were silenced by the spectacle of [his]34-berry grief . In vain [the lawyer whom [he]34-berry had secured]494-the lawyer whom he had secured showed that the evidence against [him]34-berry proved nothing . In vain [he]34-berry produced proof of the slow accumulation of what [the man]269-the man had . In vain [he]34-berry pleaded [the man]269-the man 's former good name . [The judge]497-the judge and [the jury]498-the jury saw otherwise . [Berry]34-berry was convicted . [He]34-berry was given ten years at hard labour .

[He]34-berry hardly looked as if [he]34-berry could live out one as [he]34-berry heard [his]34-berry sentence . But [Nature]75-nature was kind and relieved [him]34-berry of the strain . With a cry as if [his]34-berry heart were bursting , [he]34-berry started up and fell forward on [his]34-berry face unconscious . [Some one , a bit more brutal than the rest]499-some one , a bit more brutal than the rest , said , " It 's five dollars ' fine every time [a nigger]1722-a nigger faints , "[499-some one , a bit more brutal than the rest] but [no one]238-no one laughed . There was something too portentous , too tragic in the degradation of [this man]1709-this man .

[Maurice Oakley]39-maurice sat in [the court - room]502-the court - room , grim and relentless . As soon as the trial was over , [he]39-maurice sent for [Fannie]35-fannie , who still kept [the cottage in [the yard]136-the yard]503-the cottage in the yard .

" [You]35-fannie must go , "[39-maurice] [he]39-maurice said . " [You]35-fannie ca n't stay [here]1617-here any longer . [I]39-maurice want none of [your]35-fannie breed about [me]39-maurice . "[39-maurice]

And [Fannie]35-fannie bowed [her]35-fannie head and went away from [him]39-maurice in silence .

All the night long [the women of [the Hamilton household]506-the hamilton household]505-the women of the hamilton household lay in bed and wept , clinging to each other in [their]505-the women of the hamilton household grief . But [Joe]37-joe did not go to sleep . Against all [their]505-the women of the hamilton household entreaties , [he]37-joe stayed up . [He]37-joe put out the light and sat staring into the gloom with hard , burning eyes .

[VI

OUTCASTS]76-viola

What particularly irritated [Maurice Oakley]39-maurice was that [Berry]34-berry should to the very last keep up [his]34-berry claim of innocence . [He]39-maurice reiterated it to the very moment that [the train]372-the train which was bearing [him]34-berry away pulled out of [the station]365-the station . There had seldom been seen such an example of criminal hardihood , and [Oakley]39-maurice was hardened thereby to greater severity in dealing with [[the convict]509-the convict 's wife]510-the convict 's wife . [He]39-maurice began to urge [her]510-the convict 's wife more strongly to move , and [she]510-the convict 's wife , dispirited and humiliated by what had come to [her]510-the convict 's wife , looked vainly about for the way to satisfy [his]39-maurice demands . With [[her]510-the convict 's wife natural protector]511-her natural protector gone , [she]510-the convict 's wife felt more weak and helpless than [she]510-the convict 's wife had thought it possible to feel . It was hard enough to face [the world]1706-the world . But to have to ask something of it was almost more than [she]510-the convict 's wife could bear .

With the conviction of [[her]510-the convict 's wife husband]181-her husband the last five hundred dollars had been confiscated as belonging to the stolen money , but [their]514-they former deposit remained untouched . With this [she]510-the convict 's wife had the means at [her]510-the convict 's wife disposal to tide over [their]514-they present days of misfortune . It was not money [she]510-the convict 's wife lacked , but confidence . Some inkling of [the world]1706-the world 's attitude towards [her]510-the convict 's wife , guiltless though [she]510-the convict 's wife was , reached [her]510-the convict 's wife and made [her]510-the convict 's wife afraid .

[Her]510-the convict 's wife desperation , however , would not let [her]510-the convict 's wife give way to fear , so [she]510-the convict 's wife set forth to look for [another house]516-another house . [Joe]37-joe and [Kit]38-kitty saw [her]510-the convict 's wife go as if [she]510-the convict 's wife were starting on an expedition into [a strange country]517-a strange country . In all [their]514-they lives [they]514-they had known [no home save [the little cottage in [Oakley]39-maurice 's yard]519-the little cottage in oakley 's yard]518-no home save the little cottage in oakley 's yard . Here [they]514-they had toddled as [babies]520-babies and played as [children]521-children and been happy and care - free . There had been times when [they]514-they had complained and wanted a home off by [themselves]514-they , like [others whom [they]514-they knew]522-others whom they knew . [They]514-they had not failed , either , to draw unpleasant comparisons between [their]514-they mode of life and [the old plantation quarters]523-the old plantation quarters system . But now all this was forgotten , and there were only grief and anxiety that [they]514-they must leave [the place]357-the place and in such a way .

[Fannie]35-fannie went out with little hope in [her]35-fannie heart , and a short while after [she]35-fannie was gone [Joe]37-joe decided to follow [her]35-fannie and make an attempt to get work .

" [I]35-fannie 'll go an ' see what [I]35-fannie kin do , anyway , [Kit]38-kitty . ' T ai n't much use , [I]35-fannie reckon , trying to get into [a bahbah shop]1741-a bahbah shop where [they]1742-they shave [white folks]1688-white folks , because [all the white folks]1744-all the white folks are down on [us]1745-us . [I]35-fannie 'll try [one of [the coloured shops]1747-the coloured shops]1746-one of the coloured shops . "[35-fannie]

This was something of a condescension for [[Berry Hamilton]34-berry 's son]525-berry hamilton 's son . [He]525-berry hamilton 's son had never yet shaved a black chin or put shears to what [he]525-berry hamilton 's son termed " naps , "[525-berry hamilton 's son] and [he]525-berry hamilton 's son was proud of it . [He]525-berry hamilton 's son thought , though , that after the training [he]525-berry hamilton 's son had received from [the superior " Tonsorial Parlours "[525-berry hamilton 's son] where [he]525-berry hamilton 's son had been employed]526-the superior " tonsorial parlours " where he had been employed , [he]525-berry hamilton 's son had but to ask for a place and [he]525-berry hamilton 's son would be gladly accepted .

It is strange how all the foolish little vaunting things that [a man]1563-a man says in days of prosperity wax a giant crop around [him]1563-a man in the days of [his]1563-a man adversity . [[Berry Hamilton]34-berry 's son]525-berry hamilton 's son found this out almost as soon as [he]525-berry hamilton 's son had applied at [the first of [the coloured shops]1747-the coloured shops]529-the first of the coloured shops for work .

" Oh , no , suh , "[531-the proprietor] said [the proprietor]531-the proprietor , " [I]531-the proprietor do n't think [we]1748-we got anything fu ' [you]525-berry hamilton 's son to do ; [you]525-berry hamilton 's son 're [a white man]1749-a white man 's bahbah . [We]1748-we do n't shave nothin' but [niggahs]1750-niggahs hyeah , an ' [we]1748-we shave ['em]1750-niggahs in de light o ' day an ' on de groun ' flo ' . "[531-the proprietor]

" W'y , [I]533-a grinning negro hyeah [you]525-berry hamilton 's son say dat [you]525-berry hamilton 's son could n't git a paih of sheahs thoo a niggah 's naps . [You]525-berry hamilton 's son ai n't been practisin ' lately , has [you]525-berry hamilton 's son ? "[533-a grinning negro] came from the back of [the shop]532-the shop , where [a grinning negro]533-a grinning negro was scraping [a fellow]534-a fellow 's face .

" Oh , yes , [you]525-berry hamilton 's son 're done with burr - heads , are [you]525-berry hamilton 's son ? But burr - heads are good enough fu ' [you]525-berry hamilton 's son now . "[533-a grinning negro]

" [I]531-the proprietor think , "[531-the proprietor] [the proprietor]531-the proprietor resumed , " that [I]531-the proprietor hyeahed [you]525-berry hamilton 's son say [you]525-berry hamilton 's son was n't fond o ' grape pickin ' . Well , [Josy]77-josy , [[my]531-the proprietor son]1751-my son , [I]531-the proprietor would n't begin it now , ' specially as anothah kin ' o ' pickin ' seems to run in [yo]525-berry hamilton 's son ' fambly . "[531-the proprietor]

[Joe Hamilton]37-joe never knew how [he]37-joe got out of [that shop]536-that shop . [He]37-joe only knew that [he]37-joe found [himself]37-joe upon [the street]537-the street outside the door , tears of anger and shame in [his]37-joe eyes , and the laughs and taunts of [[his]37-joe tormentors]538-his tormentors still ringing in [his]37-joe ears .

It was cruel , of course it was cruel . It was brutal . But only [he]37-joe knew how just it had been . In [his]37-joe moments of pride [he]37-joe had said all those things , half in fun and half in earnest , and [he]37-joe began to wonder how [he]37-joe could have been so many kinds of [a fool]539-a fool for so long without realising it .

[He]37-joe had not the heart to seek [another shop]540-another shop , for [he]37-joe knew that what would be known at one would be equally well known at all the rest . The hardest thing that [he]37-joe had to bear was the knowledge that [he]37-joe had shut [himself]37-joe out of all the chances that [he]37-joe now desired . [He]37-joe remembered with a pang the words of [an old negro to whom [he]37-joe had once been impudent]541-an old negro to whom he had once been impudent , " [Nevah]60-nevah min ' , [boy]264-boy , [nevah min]1753-nevah min ' , [you]264-boy 's bo'n , but [you]264-boy ai n't daid ! "[37-joe]

It was too true . [He]37-joe had not known then what would come . [He]37-joe had never dreamed that anything so terrible could overtake [him]37-joe . Even in [his]37-joe straits , however , desperation gave [him]37-joe a certain pluck . [He]37-joe would try for something else for which [his]37-joe own tongue had not disqualified [him]37-joe . With [Joe]37-joe , to think was to do . [He]37-joe went on to [the Continental Hotel]452-the continental hotel , where there were almost always [boys]543-boys wanted to " run the bells . "[544-the clerk] [The clerk]544-the clerk looked [him]37-joe over critically . [He]37-joe was [a bright , spruce - looking young fellow]545-a bright , spruce - looking young fellow , and [the man]269-the man liked [his]37-joe looks .

" Well , [I]37-joe guess [we]1754-we can take [you]37-joe on , "[37-joe] [he]37-joe said . " What 's [your]37-joe name ? "[37-joe]

" [Joe]37-joe , "[269-the man] was the laconic answer . [He]37-joe was afraid to say more .

" Well , [Joe]37-joe , [you]37-joe go over there and sit where [you]37-joe see [those fellows in uniform]1755-those fellows in uniform , and wait until [I]548-the bellmen call [the head bellman]1756-the head bellman . "[548-the bellmen]

[Young Hamilton]78-young hamilton went over and sat down on a bench which ran along [the hotel corridor]547-the hotel corridor and where [the bellmen]548-the bellmen were wo nt to stay during the day awaiting [their]548-the bellmen calls . [A few of [the blue - coated Mercuries]550-the blue - coated mercuries]549-a few of the blue - coated mercuries were [there]1594-there . Upon [Joe]37-joe 's advent [they]548-the bellmen began to look askance at [him]37-joe and to talk among [themselves]548-the bellmen . [He]37-joe felt [his]37-joe face burning as [he]37-joe thought of what [they]548-the bellmen must be saying . Then [he]37-joe saw [the head bellman]1756-the head bellman talking to [the clerk]544-the clerk and looking in [his]37-joe direction . [He]37-joe saw [him]1756-the head bellman shake [his]1756-the head bellman head and walk away . [He]37-joe could have cursed [him]1756-the head bellman . [The clerk]544-the clerk called to [him]37-joe .

" [I]544-the clerk did n't know , "[544-the clerk] [he]544-the clerk said,--"I did n't know that [you]37-joe were [[Berry Hamilton]34-berry 's boy]1757-berry hamilton 's boy . Now , [I]544-the clerk ' ve got nothing against [you]37-joe [myself]544-the clerk . [I]544-the clerk do n't hold [you]37-joe responsible for what [[your]37-joe father]1758-your father did , but [I]544-the clerk do n't believe [[our]1759-our boys]1760-our boys would work with [you]37-joe . [I]544-the clerk ca n't take [you]37-joe on . "[544-the clerk]

[Joe]37-joe turned away to meet the grinning or contemptuous glances of [the bellmen on the seat]555-the bellmen on the seat . It would have been good to be able to hurl something among [them]555-the bellmen on the seat . But [he]37-joe was helpless .

[He]37-joe hastened out of [the hotel]556-the hotel , feeling that every eye was upon [him]37-joe , every finger pointing at [him]37-joe , every tongue whispering , " There goes [Joe Hamilton]37-joe , whose father went to [the penitentiary]1761-the penitentiary the other day . "[37-joe]

What should [he]37-joe do ? [He]37-joe could try no more . [He]37-joe was proscribed , and the letters of [his]37-joe ban were writ large throughout [the town]172-the town , where [all who ran]558-all who ran might read . For a while [he]37-joe wandered aimlessly about and then turned dejectedly homeward . [[His]37-joe mother]478-his mother had not yet come .

" Did [you]37-joe get a job ? "[38-kitty] was [Kit]38-kitty 's first question .

" No , "[37-joe] [he]37-joe answered bitterly , " [no one]238-no one wants [me]37-joe now . "[37-joe]

" [No one]238-no one wants [you]37-joe ? Why , [Joe]37-joe -- [they]1764-they -- [they]1764-they do n't think hard of [us]1765-we , do [they]1764-they ? "[38-kitty]

" [I]37-joe do n't know what [they]1764-they think of [ma]1629-ma and [you]37-joe , but [they]1764-they think hard of [me]37-joe , all right . "[37-joe]

" Oh , do n't [you]37-joe worry ; it 'll be all right when it blows over . "[38-kitty]

" Yes , when it all blows over ; but when 'll that be ? "[37-joe]

" Oh , after a while , when [we]1765-we can show ['em]1767-'em [we]1765-we 're all right . "[38-kitty]

Some of [the girl]183-the girl 's cheery hopefulness had come back to [her]183-the girl in the presence of [[her]183-the girl brother]561-her brother 's dejection , as [a woman]1566-a woman always forgets [her]1566-a woman own sorrow when [some one [she]1566-a woman loves]563-some one she loves is grieving . But [she]183-the girl could not communicate any of [her]183-the girl feeling to [Joe]37-joe , who had been and seen and felt , and now sat darkly waiting [[his]37-joe mother]478-his mother 's return . Some presentiment seemed to tell [him]37-joe that , armed as [she]183-the girl was with money to pay for what [she]183-the girl wanted and asking for nothing without price , [she]183-the girl would yet have no better tale to tell than [he]37-joe .

None of these forebodings visited the mind of [Kit]38-kitty , and as soon as [[her]183-the girl mother]174-her mother appeared on the threshold [she]183-the girl ran to [her]174-her mother , crying , " Oh , where are [we]1768-we going to live , [ma]1629-ma ? "[183-the girl]

[Fannie]35-fannie looked at [her]183-the girl for a moment , and then answered with a burst of tears , " [Gawd]59-gawd knows , [child]1770-child , [Gawd]59-gawd knows . "[35-fannie]

[The girl]183-the girl stepped back astonished . " Why , why ! "[183-the girl] and then with a rush of tenderness [she]183-the girl threw [her]183-the girl arms about [[her]183-the girl mother]174-her mother 's neck . [Fannie]35-fannie sat down and tried to drink [her]35-fannie tea , but [she]35-fannie could not . It stuck in [her]35-fannie throat , and the tears rolled down [her]35-fannie face and fell into the shaking cup . [Joe]37-joe looked on silently . [He]37-joe had been out and [he]37-joe understood .

" [I]174-her mother 'll go out to - morrow and do some looking around for [a house]1772-a house while [you]1770-child stay at [home]210-home an ' rest , [ma]1629-ma . "[174-her mother]

[[Her]35-fannie mother]174-her mother looked up , the maternal instinct for the protection of [[her]174-her mother daughter]569-her daughter at once aroused . " Oh , no , not [you]1770-child , [Kitty]38-kitty , "[174-her mother] [she]174-her mother said .

Then for the first time [Joe]37-joe spoke : " [You]1770-child 'd just as well tell [Kitty]38-kitty now , [ma]1629-ma , for [she]38-kitty 's got to come across it anyhow . "[37-joe]

" What [you]37-joe know about it ? Whaih [you]37-joe been to ? "[174-her mother]

" [I]37-joe ' ve been out huntin ' work . [I]37-joe ' ve been to [[Jones]79-mrs. jones 's bahbah shop]1776-jones 's bahbah shop an ' to [the Continental Hotel]452-the continental hotel . "[37-joe] [His]37-joe light - brown face turned brick red with anger and shame at the memory of it . " [I]37-joe do n't think [I]37-joe 'll try any more . "[37-joe]

[Kitty]38-kitty was gazing with wide and saddening eyes at [[her]38-kitty mother]174-her mother .

" Were [they]1778-they mean to [you]174-her mother too , [ma]1629-ma ? "[38-kitty] [she]38-kitty asked breathlessly .

" Mean ? Oh [Kitty]38-kitty ! [Kitty]38-kitty ! [you]38-kitty do n't know what it was like . It nigh killed [me]38-kitty . [Thaih]1780-thaih was plenty of houses an ' owned by [[people]1781-people [I]38-kitty ' ve knowed fu ' yeahs]1782-people i ' ve knowed fu ' yeahs , but not one of ['em]1783-'em wanted to rent to [me]38-kitty . [Some of ['em]1783-'em]1784-some of 'em made excuses 'bout one thing er t ' other , but de res ' come right straight out an ' said dat [we]1785-we 'd give [a neighbourhood]1786-a neighbourhood a bad name ef [we]1785-we moved into [it]1786-a neighbourhood . [I]38-kitty ' ve almos ' tramped [my]38-kitty laigs off . [I]38-kitty ' ve tried [every decent place [I]38-kitty could think of]1787-every decent place i could think of , but [nobody]1788-nobody wants [us]1785-we . "[38-kitty]

[The girl]183-the girl was standing with [her]183-the girl hands clenched nervously before [her]183-the girl . It was almost more than [she]183-the girl could understand .

" Why , [we]1785-we ai n't done anything , "[183-the girl] [she]183-the girl said . " Even if [they]1789-they do n't know any better than to believe that [pa]1790-pa was guilty , [they]1789-they know [we]1785-we ai n't done anything . "[183-the girl]

" [I]37-joe 'd like to cut the heart out of a few of 'em , "[37-joe] said [Joe]37-joe in [his]37-joe throat .

" It ai n't goin' to do no good to look at it that a - way , [Joe]37-joe , "[478-his mother] [[his]37-joe mother]478-his mother replied . " [I]478-his mother know hit 's ha'd , but [we]1785-we got to do de bes ' [we]1785-we kin . "[478-his mother]

" What are [we]1785-we goin' to do ? "[182-the boy] cried [the boy]182-the boy fiercely . " [They]1789-they wo n't let [us]1785-we work . [They]1789-they wo n't let [us]1785-we live anywhaih . Do [they]1789-they want [us]1785-we to live on [the levee]1791-the levee an ' steal , like some of ['em]1792-'em do ? "[182-the boy]

" What are [we]1785-we goin' to do ? "[38-kitty] echoed [Kitty]38-kitty helplessly . " [I]38-kitty 'd go out ef [I]38-kitty thought [I]38-kitty could find anythin ' to work at . "[38-kitty]

" Do n't [you]182-the boy go anywhaih , [child]1770-child . It ' ud only be worse . [De niggah men]1794-de niggah men dat [ust]1794-de niggah men to be bowin ' an ' scrapin ' to [me]182-the boy an ' tekin ' off [dey]1794-de niggah men hats to [me]182-the boy laughed in [my]182-the boy face . [I]182-the boy met [Minty]63-minty -- an ' [she]63-minty slurred [me]182-the boy right in [de street]1692-de street . [Dey]1794-de niggah men 'd do worse fu ' [you]182-the boy . "[182-the boy]

In the midst of the conversation a knock came at the door . It was [a messenger from [the " House]10-the " house]1796-a messenger from the " house , "[39-maurice] as [they]574-we still called [[Oakley]39-maurice 's [home]210-home]575-oakley 's home , and [he]39-maurice wanted [them]574-we to be out of [the cottage]577-the cottage by the next afternoon , as [the new servants]578-the new servants were coming and would want [the rooms]579-the rooms .

The message was so curt , so hard and decisive , that [Fannie]35-fannie was startled out of [her]35-fannie grief into immediate action .

" Well , [we]574-we got to go , "[35-fannie] [she]35-fannie said , rising wearily .

" But where are [we]574-we goin' ? "[38-kitty] wailed [Kitty]38-kitty in affright . " There 's no place to go to . [We]574-we have n't got [a house]1772-a house . Where 'll [we]574-we go ? "[38-kitty]

" Out o [' town]1798-' town someplace as fur away from [this damned hole]1799-this damned hole as [we]574-we kin git . "[182-the boy] [The boy]182-the boy spoke recklessly in [his]182-the boy anger . [He]182-the boy had never sworn before [[his]182-the boy mother]478-his mother before .

[She]478-his mother looked at [him]182-the boy in horror . " [Joe]37-joe , [Joe]37-joe , "[478-his mother] [she]478-his mother said , " [you]37-joe 're mekin ' it wuss . [You]37-joe 're mekin ' it ha'dah fu ' [me]478-his mother to [baih]1800-baih when [you]37-joe talk dat a - way . What [you]37-joe mean ? Whaih [you]37-joe think [Gawd]59-gawd is ? "[478-his mother]

[Joe]37-joe remained sullenly silent . [[His]182-the boy mother]478-his mother 's faith was too stalwart for [his]37-joe comprehension . There was nothing like it in [his]37-joe own soul to interpret it .

" [We]583-we 'll git de secon'-han ' dealah to tek ouah things to - morrer , an ' then [we]583-we 'll go away some place , up No'th maybe . "[478-his mother]

" Let 's go to [New York]8-new york , "[37-joe] said [Joe]37-joe .

" [New Yo'k]11-new yo'k ? "[478-his mother]

[They]583-we had heard of [New York]8-new york as [a place vague and far away]584-a place vague and far away , [a city that , like [Heaven]12-heaven , to [them]583-we had existed by faith alone]585-a city that , like heaven , to them had existed by faith alone . All the days of [their]583-we lives [they]583-we had heard of it , and it seemed to [them]583-we the centre of all the glory , all the wealth , and all the freedom of [the world]1706-the world . [New York]8-new york . [It]8-new york had an alluring sound . Who would know [them]583-we there ? Who would look down upon [them]583-we ?

" It 's a mighty long ways off fu ' [me]182-the boy to be sta'tin ' at dis time o ' life . "[182-the boy]

" [We]583-we want to go a long ways off . "[182-the boy]

" [I]38-kitty wonder what [pa]1790-pa would think of it if [he]1790-pa was [here]1617-here , "[38-kitty] put in [Kitty]38-kitty .

" [I]182-the boy guess [he]1790-pa 'd think [we]583-we was doin' the best [we]583-we could . "[182-the boy]

" Well , den , [Joe]37-joe , "[478-his mother] said [[his]587-his mother]478-his mother , [her]478-his mother voice trembling with emotion at the daring step [they]583-we were about to take , " [you]37-joe set down an ' write a lettah to [[yo]587-his ' pa]1803-yo ' pa , an ' tell [him]1790-pa what [we]583-we goin' to do , an ' to - morrer -- to - morrer -- [we]583-we 'll sta't . "[478-his mother]

Something akin to joy came into [the boy]182-the boy 's heart as [he]182-the boy sat down to write the letter . [They]583-we had taunted [him]182-the boy , had [they]583-we ? [They]583-we had scoffed at [him]182-the boy . But [he]182-the boy was going where [they]583-we might never go , and some day [he]182-the boy would come back holding [his]182-the boy head high and pay [them]583-we sneer for sneer and jibe for jibe .

The same night the commission was given to [the furniture dealer who would take charge of [their]583-we things and sell [them]583-we when and for what [he]590-the furniture dealer who would take charge of their things and sell them when and for what he could could]590-the furniture dealer who would take charge of their things and sell them when and for what he could .

From [his]182-the boy window the next morning [Maurice Oakley]39-maurice watched [the wagon]591-the wagon emptying [the house]1558-the house . Then [he]182-the boy saw [Fannie]35-fannie come out and walk about [[her]35-fannie little garden]593-her little garden , followed by [[her]35-fannie children]594-her children . [He]182-the boy saw [her]35-fannie as [she]35-fannie wiped [her]35-fannie eyes and led the way to the side gate .

" Well , [they]594-her children 're gone , "[182-the boy] [he]182-the boy said to [[his]182-the boy wife]133-his wife . " [I]182-the boy wonder where [they]594-her children 're going to live ? "[182-the boy]

" Oh , [some of [[their]594-her children people]1805-their people]1804-some of their people will take [them]594-her children in , "[40-mrs. oakley] replied [Mrs. Oakley]40-mrs. oakley languidly .

Despite the fact that [[his]182-the boy mother]478-his mother carried with [her]478-his mother the rest of the money drawn from the bank , [Joe]37-joe had suddenly stepped into [the place of [the man of [the family]208-the family]598-the man of the family]597-the place of the man of the family . [He]37-joe attended to all the details of [their]208-the family getting away with a promptness that made it seem untrue that [he]37-joe had never been more than thirty miles from [[his]37-joe native town]600-his native town . [He]37-joe was eager and excited . As [the train]372-the train drew out of [the station]365-the station , [he]37-joe did not look back upon [the place which [he]37-joe hated]603-the place which he hated , but [Fannie]35-fannie and [[her]35-fannie daughter]569-her daughter let [their]208-the family eyes linger upon [it]603-the place which he hated until [the last house]605-the last house , [the last chimney]606-the last chimney , and the last spire faded from [their]208-the family sight , and [their]208-the family tears fell and mingled as [they]208-the family were whirled away toward [the unknown]607-the unknown .

VII

IN [NEW YORK]8-new york

To [the provincial]608-the provincial coming to [New York]8-new york for the first time , ignorant and unknown , [the city]609-the city presents a notable mingling of the qualities of cheeriness and gloom . If [he]37-joe have any eye at all for the beautiful , [he]37-joe can not help experiencing a thrill as [he]37-joe crosses [the ferry]610-the ferry over [the river]611-the river filled with [plying craft]612-plying craft and catches the first sight of [the spires and buildings of [New York]8-new york]613-the spires and buildings of new york . If [he]37-joe have the right stuff in [him]37-joe , a something will take possession of [him]37-joe that will grip [him]37-joe again every time [he]37-joe returns to the scene and will make [him]37-joe long and hunger for [the place]357-the place when [he]37-joe is away from [it]357-the place . Later , the lights in [the busy streets]615-the busy streets will bewilder and entice [him]37-joe . [He]37-joe will feel shy and helpless amid [the hurrying crowds]616-the hurrying crowds . A new emotion will take [his]37-joe heart as [the people]617-the people hasten by [him,--a]618-him,--a feeling of loneliness , almost of grief , that with all of these souls about [him]37-joe [he]37-joe knows not one and [not one of [them]617-the people]619-not one of them cares for [him]37-joe . After a while [he]37-joe will find [a place]620-a place and give a sigh of relief as [he]37-joe settles away from [the city]609-the city 's sights behind [his]37-joe cosey blinds . It is better here , and [the city]609-the city is cruel and cold and unfeeling . This [he]37-joe will feel , perhaps , for the first half - hour , and then [he]37-joe will be out in it all again . [He]37-joe will be glad to strike elbows with [the bustling mob]623-the bustling mob and be happy at [their]623-the bustling mob indifference to [him]37-joe , so that [he]37-joe may look at [them]623-the bustling mob and study [them]623-the bustling mob . After it is all over , after [he]37-joe has passed through the first pangs of strangeness and homesickness , yes , even after [he]37-joe has got beyond [the stranger]624-the stranger 's enthusiasm for [the metropolis]625-the metropolis , the real fever of love for [the place]357-the place will begin to take hold upon [him]37-joe . The subtle , insidious wine of [New York]8-new york will begin to intoxicate [him]37-joe . Then , if [he]37-joe be wise , [he]37-joe will go away , any place,--yes , [he]37-joe will even go over to [Jersey]13-jersey . But if [he]37-joe be [a fool]539-a fool , [he]37-joe will stay and stay on until [the town]172-the town becomes all in all to [him]37-joe ; until [the very streets]629-the very streets are [his]37-joe chums and [certain buildings]630-certain buildings and corners [[his]37-joe best friends]631-his best friends . Then [he]37-joe is hopeless , and to live elsewhere would be death . [The Bowery]632-the bowery will be [his]37-joe romance , Broadway [his]37-joe lyric , and the Park [[his]37-joe pastoral]633-his pastoral , [the river]611-the river and the glory of it all [his]37-joe epic , and [he]37-joe will look down pityingly on [all the rest of humanity]635-all the rest of humanity .

It was the afternoon of a clear October day that [the Hamiltons]33-the hamiltons reached [New York]8-new york . [Fannie]35-fannie had some misgivings about crossing [the ferry]610-the ferry , but once on [the boat]637-the boat these gave way to speculations as to what [they]33-the hamiltons should find on the other side . With the eagerness of [youth]638-youth to take in new impressions , [Joe]37-joe and [Kitty]38-kitty were more concerned with what [they]33-the hamiltons saw about [them]33-the hamiltons than with what [their]33-the hamiltons future would hold , though [they]33-the hamiltons might well have stopped to ask some such questions . In all [the great city]639-the great city [they]33-the hamiltons knew absolutely [no one]238-no one , and had no idea which way to go to find [a stopping - place]641-a stopping - place .

[They]33-the hamiltons looked about [them]33-the hamiltons for some coloured face , and finally saw one among [the porters who were handling the baggage]642-the porters who were handling the baggage . To [Joe]37-joe 's inquiry [he]37-joe gave [them]33-the hamiltons an address , and also proffered [his]37-joe advice as to the best way to reach [the place]357-the place . [He]37-joe was exceedingly polite , and [he]37-joe looked hard at [Kitty]38-kitty . [They]33-the hamiltons found [the house to which [they]33-the hamiltons had been directed]644-the house to which they had been directed , and were a good deal surprised at [its]644-the house to which they had been directed apparent grandeur . [It]644-the house to which they had been directed was [a four - storied brick dwelling on [Twenty - seventh Street]14-twenty - seventh street]645-a four - storied brick dwelling on twenty - seventh street . As [they]33-the hamiltons looked from the outside , [they]33-the hamiltons were afraid that the price of staying in [such a place]646-such a place would be too much for [their]33-the hamiltons pockets . Inside , the sight of the hard , gaudily upholstered instalment - plan furniture did not disillusion [them]33-the hamiltons , and [they]33-the hamiltons continued to fear that [they]33-the hamiltons could never stop at [this fine place]647-this fine place . But [they]33-the hamiltons found [Mrs. Jones]79-mrs. jones , [the proprietress]648-the proprietress , both gracious and willing to come to terms with [them]33-the hamiltons .

As [Mrs. Hamilton]45-mrs. hamilton -- [she]45-mrs. hamilton began to be [Mrs. Hamilton]45-mrs. hamilton now , to the exclusion of [Fannie]35-fannie -- would have described [Mrs. Jones]79-mrs. jones , [she]79-mrs. jones was [a " big yellow woman]1806-a " big yellow woman . "[79-mrs. jones] [She]79-mrs. jones had a broad good - natured face and a tendency to run to bust .

" Yes , "[79-mrs. jones] [she]79-mrs. jones said , " [I]79-mrs. jones think [I]79-mrs. jones could arrange to take [you]1807-you . [I]79-mrs. jones could let [you]1807-you have [two rooms]1808-two rooms , and [you]1807-you could use [[my]79-mrs. jones kitchen]1809-my kitchen until [you]1807-you decided whether [you]1807-you wanted to take [a flat]1810-a flat or not . [I]79-mrs. jones has [the whole house]1811-the whole house [myself]79-mrs. jones , and [I]79-mrs. jones keeps [roomers]1812-roomers . But latah on [I]79-mrs. jones could fix things so 's [you]1807-you could have [the whole third floor]1813-the whole third floor ef [you]1807-you wanted to . [Most o ' [[my]79-mrs. jones gent'men]1815-my gent'men 's [railroad gent'men]1816-railroad gent'men]1814-most o ' my gent'men 's railroad gent'men , [they]1814-most o ' my gent'men 's railroad gent'men is . [I]79-mrs. jones guess it must ' a ' been [Mr. Thomas]80-thomas that sent [you]1807-you up here . "[79-mrs. jones]

" [He]80-thomas was [a little bright man down at [de deepo]0-de deepo]1817-a little bright man down at de deepo . "[79-mrs. jones]

" Yes , that 's [him]80-thomas . That 's [Mr. Thomas]80-thomas . [He]80-thomas 's always lookin ' out to send [some one]1642-some one [here]1617-here , because [he]80-thomas 's been here three years hisself an ' [he]80-thomas kin recommend [[my]79-mrs. jones house]1820-my house . "[79-mrs. jones]

It was a relief to [the Hamiltons]33-the hamiltons to find [Mrs. Jones]79-mrs. jones so gracious and [home]210-home - like . So the matter was settled , and [they]33-the hamiltons took up [[their]33-the hamiltons abode]650-their abode with [her]79-mrs. jones and sent for [their]33-the hamiltons baggage .

With the first pause in the rush that [they]33-the hamiltons had experienced since starting away from [home]210-home , [Mrs. Hamilton]45-mrs. hamilton began to have time for reflection , and [their]33-the hamiltons condition seemed to [her]79-mrs. jones much better as it was . Of course , it was hard to be away from [home]210-home and among [strangers]653-strangers , but the arrangement had this advantage,--that [no one]238-no one knew [them]33-the hamiltons or could taunt [them]33-the hamiltons with [their]33-the hamiltons past trouble . [She]79-mrs. jones was not sure that [she]79-mrs. jones was going to like [New York]8-new york . [It]8-new york had a great name and was really [a great place]655-a great place , but the very bigness of it frightened [her]79-mrs. jones and made [her]79-mrs. jones feel alone , for [she]79-mrs. jones knew that there could not be [so many people]656-so many people together without a deal of wickedness . [She]79-mrs. jones did not argue the complement of this , that the amount of good would also be increased , but this was because to [her]79-mrs. jones evil was the very present factor in [her]79-mrs. jones life .

[Joe]37-joe and [Kit]38-kitty were differently affected by what [they]657-they saw about [them]657-they . [The boy]182-the boy was wild with enthusiasm and with a desire to be a part of all that [the metropolis]625-the metropolis meant . In the evening [he]182-the boy saw [the young fellows]660-the young fellows passing by dressed in [their]660-the young fellows spruce clothes , and [he]182-the boy wondered with a sort of envy where [they]660-the young fellows could be going . Back [home]210-home there had been no place much worth going to , except [church]662-church and [[one or two people]663-one or two people 's houses]664-one or two people 's houses . But [these young fellows]665-these young fellows seemed to show by [their]665-these young fellows manners that [they]665-these young fellows were neither going to [church]662-church nor [a family]667-a family visiting . In the moment that [he]182-the boy recognised this , a revelation came to [him,--the]668-him,--the knowledge that [his]182-the boy horizon had been very narrow , and [he]182-the boy felt angry that it was so . Why should [those fellows]669-those fellows be different from [him]182-the boy ? Why should [they]669-those fellows walk [the streets]484-the streets so knowingly , so independently , when [he]182-the boy knew not whither to turn [his]182-the boy steps ? Well , [he]182-the boy was in [New York]8-new york , and now [he]182-the boy would learn . Some day [some greenhorn from [the South]1-the south]671-some greenhorn from the south should stand at a window and look out envying [him]182-the boy , as [he]182-the boy passed , red - cravated , patent - leathered , intent on some goal . Was it not better , after all , that circumstances had forced [them]669-those fellows thither ? Had it not been so , [they]669-those fellows might all have stayed [home]210-home and stagnated . Well , thought [he]182-the boy , it 's an ill wind that blows nobody good , and somehow , with a guilty under - thought , [he]182-the boy forgot to feel the natural pity for [[his]182-the boy father]180-his father , toiling guiltless in the prison of [[his]180-his father native State]674-his native state .

Whom [the Gods]675-the gods wish to destroy [they]675-the gods first make mad . The first sign of the demoralisation of [the provincial who comes to [New York]8-new york]676-the provincial who comes to new york is [his]182-the boy pride at [his]182-the boy insensibility to certain impressions which used to influence [him]182-the boy at [home]210-home . First , [he]182-the boy begins to scoff , and there is no truth in [his]182-the boy views nor depth in [his]182-the boy laugh . But by and by , from mere pretending , it becomes real . [He]182-the boy grows callous . After that [he]182-the boy goes to the devil very cheerfully .

No such radical emotions , however , troubled [Kit]38-kitty 's mind . [She]38-kitty too stood at the windows and looked down into [the street]537-the street . There was a sort of complacent calm in the manner in which [she]38-kitty viewed [the girls]679-the girls ' hats and dresses . Many of [them]679-the girls were really pretty , [she]38-kitty told [herself]38-kitty , but for the most part [they]679-the girls were not better than what [she]38-kitty had had down [home]210-home . There was a sound quality in [the girl]183-the girl 's make - up that helped [her]38-kitty to see through the glamour of mere place and recognise worth for [itself]682-itself . Or it may have been the critical faculty , which is prominent in [most women]683-most women , that kept [her]38-kitty from thinking a five - cent cheese - cloth any better in [New York]8-new york than it was at [home]210-home . [She]38-kitty had a certain self - respect which made [her]38-kitty value [herself]38-kitty and [her]38-kitty own traditions higher than [[her]38-kitty brother]561-her brother did [his]561-her brother .

When later in the evening [the porter who had been kind to [them]687-them]686-the porter who had been kind to them came in and was introduced as [Mr. William Thomas]80-thomas , young as [she]686-the porter who had been kind to them was , [she]686-the porter who had been kind to them took [his]80-thomas open admiration for [her]686-the porter who had been kind to them with more coolness than [Joe]37-joe exhibited when [Thomas]80-thomas offered to show [him]80-thomas something of [the town]172-the town some day or night .

[Mr. Thomas]80-thomas was [a loquacious little man]689-a loquacious little man with a confident air born of an intense admiration of [himself]80-thomas . [He]80-thomas was [the idol of a number of]690-the idol of a number of [servant - girls]691-servant - girls ' hearts , and altogether [a decidedly dashing back - area - way [Don Juan]81-don juan]692-a decidedly dashing back - area - way don juan .

" [I]80-thomas tell [you]686-the porter who had been kind to them , [Miss Kitty]38-kitty , "[80-thomas] [he]80-thomas burst forth , a few minutes after being introduced , " [they]1821-they ai n't no use talkin ' , [N]1822-n ' [Yawk]1823-yawk 'll give [you]686-the porter who had been kind to them a shakin ' up ' at [you]686-the porter who had been kind to them wo n't soon forget . [It]172-the town 's [the only town on [the face of the earth]1825-the face of the earth]1824-the only town on the face of the earth . [We]1826-we git the best shows here , [we]1826-we git the best concerts -- say , now , what 's the use o ' [my]80-thomas callin ' it all out?--we simply git the best of everything . "[80-thomas]

" Great place , "[37-joe] said [Joe]37-joe wisely , in what [he]37-joe thought was going to be quite a man - of - the - world manner . But [he]37-joe burned with shame the next minute because [his]37-joe voice sounded so weak and youthful . Then too [the oracle]693-the oracle only said " Yes "[693-the oracle] to [him]37-joe , and went on expatiating to [Kitty]38-kitty on the glories of [the metropolis]625-the metropolis .

" [D'jever]1827-d'jever see [the statue o ' [Liberty]16-liberty]1828-the statue o ' liberty ? Great thing , the statue o ' [Liberty]16-liberty . " [La]18-la , [Thomas]80-thomas , "[79-mrs. jones] [Mrs. Jones]79-mrs. jones put in , " how [you]80-thomas do run on ! Why , [the strangers]1830-the strangers 'll think [they]1830-the strangers 'll be talked to death before [they]1830-the strangers have time to breathe . "[79-mrs. jones]

" Oh , [I]693-the oracle guess [the folks understan ' [me]693-the oracle]1831-the folks understan ' me . [Mr. Thomas]80-thomas took the pail and went to the corner . As [he]80-thomas left [the room]292-the room , [Mrs. Jones]79-mrs. jones slapped [her]79-mrs. jones knee and laughed until [her]79-mrs. jones bust shook like jelly .

" [Mr. Thomas]80-thomas is [a case]1838-a case , sho ' , "[79-mrs. jones] [she]79-mrs. jones said ; " but [he]80-thomas likes [you]1835-you all , an ' [I]79-mrs. jones ' m mighty glad of it , fu ' [he]80-thomas 's mighty curious about [the house]1558-the house when [he]80-thomas do n't like [the roomers]1840-the roomers . "[79-mrs. jones]

[Joe]37-joe felt distinctly flattered , for [he]37-joe found [[their]696-their new acquaintance]697-their new acquaintance charming . [[His]37-joe mother]478-his mother was still a little doubtful , and [Kitty]38-kitty was sure [she]38-kitty found [the young man]304-the young man " fresh . "[38-kitty]

[He]304-the young man came in pretty soon with [his]304-the young man beer , and a half - dozen crabs in a bag .

" Thought [I]38-kitty 'd bring [home]210-home something to chew . [I]38-kitty always like to eat something with [my]38-kitty beer . "[38-kitty]

[Joe]37-joe felt as if the " chillen "[38-kitty] had ruined all [his]37-joe hopes , but [Kitty]38-kitty rose .

[The ingratiating " N ' Yawker]1843-the ingratiating " n ' yawker "[1843-the ingratiating " n ' yawker] was aghast .

" Yes , that 's it , [Miss Kitty]38-kitty , sing [us]1849-us something , "[80-thomas] said the irrepressible [Thomas]80-thomas , " an ' after while [we]1849-us 'll have that fellah down that plays ' Rag - time . ' [He]37-joe 's out o ' sight , [I]80-thomas tell [you]38-kitty . "[80-thomas]

With the pretty shyness of girlhood , [Kitty]38-kitty sang one or two little songs in the simple manner [she]38-kitty knew . [Her]38-kitty voice was full and rich . It delighted [Mr. Thomas]80-thomas .

" [I]80-thomas say , that 's singin ' now , [I]80-thomas tell [you]38-kitty , "[80-thomas] [he]80-thomas cried . " [You]38-kitty ought to have some o ' the new songs . D ' jever hear ' [Baby]1850-baby , [you]38-kitty got to leave ' ? [I]80-thomas tell [you]38-kitty , that 's a hot one . [I]80-thomas 'll bring [you]38-kitty some of 'em . Why , [you]38-kitty could git a job on the stage easy with that voice o ' yourn .
